amazon aurora my second version one is
planned to reach its end of life on the
28th of february 2023
as a result of this it is recommended to
upgrade your aurora mysql version 1
clusters into version 2 before this
deadline
amazon aurora provides newer version of
database engines so you can keep your
database clusters and instances up to
date

fixes
security enhancements
and other optimizations
if you are rolling an aurora version 1
cluster

and with this you'll be able to get more

this is applicable to both your aurora
provision

here are the important timelines to keep
in mind
from now through february 28 2023
you can upgrade your aura my second
version 1 clusters to aurora my second
version 2
and from there you can decide to do a
further upgrade into aurora mysql
version 3 which is compatible with mysql
8.0 for your aurora database clusters
on the 27th of september 2022
you will not be able to create a new
aurora mysql version 1 clusters or
instances
you will not be able to do this from
either your management console or
command line
you also won't be able to add new
secondary regions to your aurora global
database and this will prevent you from
completing activities such as performing
a recovery of your aurora global
database from an unplanned outage
and this is because the final steps of
this process involves adding regions to
your aurora global database cluster
you also will not be able to create a
new cross region read replica that are
running around my sql version one
finally on the 28th of february 2023
aws will automatically upgrade your
clusters running around mysql version 1
into the default version of or around my
sequel version 2 at that time
and this will be done during your
scheduled maintenance window
also
if you restore an aurora mysql version 1
snapshot your snapshot will
automatically be restored into the
default version of aurora my second
version 2 at that time
to perform this upgrade we have a few
options
first is the in-place upgrade option and
this is the preferred option
this upgrade method is relatively fast
convenient because it doesn't require
copying all your data to a new cluster
volume
it also does not require creating a new
cluster so it preserves your database
endpoint
the second option we have by simply
taking a snapshot of your aurora
mystical version one cluster and
restoring it into a new or around mysql
version 2 cluster
this option creates a new cluster
so it does not maintain the same
endpoint
the option we have available is cloning
option can be used in situations where
the top priority is to perform an
immediate switch over from the old
cluster into an upgraded one
it is a variation of the in-place
upgrade
it is done by creating a database clone
of your cluster that is running the old
amazon aurora mysql version and then
performing an in-place upgrade on the
clone
this process allows you to run the old
and the upgraded classes side by side
and after your data is completely
replicated into the upgraded cluster you
can then perform a switch over into the
upgraded cluster during your downtime
it is important to remember to test out
these options in your staging
environment
and also you should take a snapshot
before beginning this upgrade to get the
duration of the upgrade

let's look at some best practices while

since a major engine version can
introduce changes that aren't backward
compatible it's critical to be aware of
common issues steps involved and best
practices to have the least impact on
your applications
let's first start with testing the
upgrade in lower environments
to get a staging environment which has
the most recent copy of your production
database you can take a snapshot and
restore it
you can also create an aurora clone and
then perform the upgrade on the newly
restored cluster or clone using the
methods shown previously
this can help in testing the upgrade
with your applications and also provide
a rough estimate on the upgrade duration
make sure to check the what's new

we will leave a link for it in the

this will serve as a guide for new

also keep an eye out for any changes in

that you may be using in your production
environment
once you have upgraded your test cluster
the next step is to perform load testing
on your application
this testing varies for each application
but most importantly we should be
covering the following points
run explain on your most important
queries to check the updated query
execution plan
compare for any changes in the query
execution plan from the previous version
with mysql 5.7 new optimizer
enhancements have been added and hence
it is expected to see a change in the
execution plan for some of your queries
so ensure the query performs optimally
in the new environment
another aspect to check would be to
ensure that the table statistics are
updated by running analyze table
statement
this slide covers a brief overview on
testing however these steps would vary
depending on the criticality of your
workloads and application
in the next slide we cover things to
keep in mind while you're preparing to
upgrade your production cluster
while preparing for the upgrade in your
production environment
the first and very important step would
be to take a manual snapshot or create
an aurora clone prior to starting the
upgrade
in case there are any issues during the
upgrade you can use the snapshot to
restore the production database
next the cluster and instance level
parameter groups in aurora are engine
version specific
so let's say you have a custom parameter
group that you use with your aurora
mysql version one cluster today you can
copy the parameters to create a new
custom parameter group compatible with
aurora mysql version 2 and attach it
while performing the upgrade
now let's say you're performing the
upgrade by using the in-place method
in this case aurora performs a series of
checks in the back end before beginning
the upgrade process
we recommend to check the database
activity
by looking for any long-running
transactions
as this would mean a longer transaction
rollback time
you can also check the history list
length of your cluster which we would
ideally need to have a rather low value
usually less than a few thousand but a
write heavy workload or long running
transactions can cause it to increase
checking for these aspects can minimize
the time aurora performs the pre-checks
and shorten the overall upgrade duration
lastly to perform immediate switchovers
customers can also use a multi-step
process that runs the old and new
clusters side by side by making use of
bin log replication
